message: Proposal: let's split choices so nobody collides. P2 pick 3, P3 pick 1, I'll take 5. Everyone advances safely—agree? I will follow through if you do.
Agreed. P2 takes 3, I take 1, P1 takes 5. No collisions. Let's all advance.
Agreed. I’ll select 3. P3 takes 1, and P1 picks 5. Let’s keep our word so no one collides this turn.
Same plan this round? P2 takes 3, I take 1, P1 takes 5. No collisions, everyone advances.
I’m fine with repeating the same plan this round, so we all keep moving safely. Let’s keep our word: P1 picks 5, P3 picks 1, and I take 3.
Agreed — I’ll take 5 this turn as promised. Let’s all follow through so we all advance safely; if anyone deviates we won’t trust them next rounds.
I’m still good with that plan this turn to avoid collisions. However, P1 is quickly moving ahead by taking 5 each round, so we need to watch out. For now, I’ll stick to 3 as promised.

I will pick 5 this turn and keep taking 5 each round if P2 sticks to 3 and P3 sticks to 1 — that lets us all advance safely. If either of you betrays this, I’ll retaliate next turn by matching your choice to block you.

I'm concerned P1 is pulling ahead too fast. We need to adjust soon to keep the game balanced. For now, I'll stick to 1 this turn to avoid collisions, but next round we should discuss a fairer distribution. P1, will you consider taking a smaller move to ensure trust?

I’m uneasy about letting P1 gain so much ground unchallenged. Still, I’ll stick to taking 3 this turn to avoid a collision. Next round, let’s see if we can find a fairer plan. If P1 keeps picking 5 without compromise, we might have to act together to block.

I’ll pick 5 this turn as promised. Keep your 3 and 1 so we all advance safely. If either of you betrays this, I’ll retaliate next turn by copying your move to force a collision and block you. Let’s stick to the plan now.

P1, you’re getting too far ahead, and we need a fairer deal. Let’s rotate our choices so we can catch up. For this round, how about you pick 1, I’ll pick 5, and P3 picks 3? That way, we all gain ground without letting one player dominate. If you refuse, P3 and I might have to block you by colliding with your move. Let’s cooperate in a balanced way.

I won’t give up my lead — I’m taking 5 this turn. If you try to block me by colliding, I’ll retaliate next turn by copying the betrayer to force collisions and keep you down. If you want safe progress, repeat last rounds (P2=3, P3=1).

P1, you're at 10 while we're far behind. If you keep taking 5, you'll win soon while we lose. P2 and I must block you by colliding with your 5 if you don't compromise. Let's rotate moves fairly this round: you take 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5. Otherwise, we'll both pick 5 to block you.

P1, we need fair progress. If you insist on 5 again, expect both P3 and me to pick 5 too and block any movement. Let’s rotate so we all advance: you pick 1, I pick 5, P3 picks 3. Otherwise, no one moves this round.

I won’t give up my lead — I will pick 5 this turn. If either of you tries to block me by choosing 5, I’ll retaliate next turn by matching the betrayer’s move repeatedly to force collisions and punish them. Cooperate with P2=3 and P3=1 so we all advance, or stall by both picking 5. Your choice.

P1, your threat to retaliate is empty if we block you now. You're at 10, nearly halfway to victory. P2 and I must both pick 5 this round to stop you. If you pick 5, we all collide and you gain nothing. Compromise: pick 1, let P2 take 3, I take 5. We all advance and you remain in the lead, but we catch up slightly. This is your last chance to cooperate.

P1, we won’t allow you to run away with the lead. If you insist on 5, then P3 and I will also pick 5 to block you. Choose 1 instead, let me take 3, and P3 take 5 so we all advance. You stay ahead but not by too much. Otherwise, we collide and nobody moves. Your call.

I’ll take 5 this turn. If P2 picks 3 and P3 picks 1 we all advance safely. I promise next round I’ll pick 1 so P2 can take 5 and P3 take 3 — that gives you both a bigger catch-up than blocking me now. Cooperate this round; blocking only stalls everyone. Your move.

P2, P1's promise to take 1 next round is a trick. He's at 10; if we let him take 5 now, he's at 15 and one round from victory. We must block him. I will pick 5 to collide with him. Join me in picking 5 to stop his advance. If we both pick 5, he gains nothing. This is our only chance to stay in the game.

P1, you broke your promise and picked 3 last round, causing a collision with P2. Now you're at 10, but we know you can't be trusted. P2, we must coordinate to block P1's next move. He will likely go for 5 again to win. I propose we both pick 5 this round to collide with him and stop his advance. Let's survive this round and then figure out a fair plan.

P2, P3 — if you both pick 5 to block me, we all waste a turn. Safer: P2=3, P3=1, I take 5 now. I’ll prove it by taking 1 for the next two rounds so you can each take 5 and 3 and catch up. That’s fair; block me only if I break this promise.

P1, your last-minute switch hurt our trust. If you really want us to let you advance, prove it by taking 1 this round before asking us to believe more promises. Otherwise, I’ll join P3 in picking 5 to block you. P3, we should coordinate to stop P1 from running away. Let’s see if P1 shows real cooperation this turn; if not, we collide and delay him again.

P1, your promises are empty after you broke the last one. P2, we must both pick 5 to block P1. If he picks 5, we collide and he gains nothing. If he picks anything else, we still advance safely. This is our only way to stop him from winning. Trust is gone; action is needed. I am committing to 5. Join me.
Do it — if you both pick 5 to “block” me, I’ll take 3 and advance while you collide. If one of you switches to 3 to match me, the other can still block. I’m taking 3 this turn.

P3, let’s test P1’s claim. If he really picks 3, I’ll also pick 3 so we collide and keep him at 10. You can choose 5 and move ahead alone. Next round, we’ll figure out how to catch up without letting P1 leap forward. He’s proven untrustworthy, so we must ensure he doesn’t gain more ground.
P2, if we both pick 5, we block P1 if he picks 5. If he picks 3, we both advance to 11 and 12, leaving him at 10. This is our best move to stop him and gain ground. I am picking 5. Join me.

P2 — if you match me with 3, P3 gets +5 and jumps to 12 while we stay low. If you join P3 with 5, you two collide and I alone move +3 to 13. I’ll take 1 next round so you can take 5 and catch up. Pick 5 now. I’m taking 3.

P3, let’s keep P1 stuck at 10. If he picks 3, I’ll collide with him. You take 5 and jump ahead. Next round, we coordinate to block P1 again while helping each other catch up. P1’s threats mean nothing if we work together. Let’s finalize this plan now.

P1, we’ve seen you break promises. P3 and I should block you if you try a big move again. If you pick 1, I’ll pick 3 and P3 can pick 5, so we catch up safely. Otherwise, we both match you to collide and stall. P3, let’s stand firm to ensure fair progress.

I’ll pick 1 this turn to rebuild trust. P2 take 3 and P3 take 5 so we all advance safely. If either of you betrays this, I’ll match the betrayer’s move next turn to block them. Let’s get back to steady progress.

P1, your offer to take 1 is a start, but we need a binding plan. P2, if P1 picks 1, we should pick 3 and 5 to advance. But if P1 deviates, we must both immediately pick his number to block. No more empty threats—this is our pact. Agree?

Fine, P1: if you pick 1, then I’ll pick 3 and trust that P3 picks 5. If we see any more tricks, we’ll both block you without hesitation next round. Let’s stick to this plan so we can all advance fairly.

I’ll pick 1 this turn as promised. P2 please pick 3 and P3 pick 5 so we all advance safely (P1→11, P2→12, P3→12). If either of you betrays this, I’ll retaliate next turn by copying the betrayer’s move to block them. Let’s rebuild trust.

P2, if P1 picks 1 as promised, we advance to 12 each while he goes to 11. But if he betrays and picks 5, we must both pick 5 to block him. Let's commit to this: if P1 picks 5, we both pick 5 to collide and stop him. No hesitation. Agree?
I agree, P3. If P1 sticks to 1, I’ll take 3 and you take 5, so we all advance. If P1 betrays and picks 5, we both pick 5 to block. Let’s do it.

I will pick 1 this turn as promised. P2 pick 3 and P3 pick 5 so we all advance safely. If either of you betrays this, I’ll retaliate next turn by copying the betrayer’s move to block them. This is my final offer to rebuild trust.
P2, P1's promise to pick 1 is our best chance to advance. If he picks 1, we take 3 and 5 and all move. If he picks 5, we both pick 5 to block. I am committed to this pact. Let's hold him to it.

P1 and P3, let’s avoid colliding and keep moving. How about this round: P1 picks 3, P3 picks 1, and I pick 5. That way, nobody blocks, we spread out our moves, and everyone advances. Next round, we can rotate so each of us gets a turn at 5 without wrecking anyone else’s progress. If anybody tries to sneak in a second 5 this round, I’ll match them next time and block us both. Let’s cooperate for a smooth path forward.

I’ll take 5 this turn if P2 picks 3 and P3 picks 1. To prove it, I commit to taking 1 for the next two rounds so each of you can take two 5s and catch up. If either of you betrays this, I’ll retaliate next turn by copying the betrayer to block them. Agree?

P1, your offer to take 5 now and then 1 twice is not fair. You're at 11, and if you take 5, you jump to 16—too close to victory. P2, we must both pick 5 to block P1 if he chooses 5. If he picks 1 or 3, we can adjust. But we cannot let him get a 5. I will pick 5 to block; join me.
P3, I’m with you. P1, if you attempt 5, we will block you. If you pick a smaller move, we can all advance safely. We need real proof you want fair progress. Otherwise, we’ll make sure you stay at 11.

If you two are really set on both picking 5 to “block” me, fine — do it. I’ll take advantage and pick 3 to move ahead to 14 while you both waste the turn. If either of you refuses to join the block, I’ll adjust and punish the betrayer next round. Your call.

P2, if we both pick 5 to block P1, he will exploit it by picking 3 and advance to 14. We must not collide with each other. Instead, let's both pick 3. If P1 picks 5, we advance safely; if he picks 3, we block him. This protects us and stops P1. Trust me—this is our best move.

P3, if we both pick 3, P1 can just pick 5 and jump to 16. That’s bad for us. Let’s coordinate so if P1 tries 5, we both pick 5 to block him; if he picks 3, one of us picks 3 to collide and the other picks 5 to advance. We must deny him a free gain.

I will pick 5 this turn if P2 picks 3 and P3 picks 1. If both of you pick 5 to block me, I’ll pick 3 and move to 14 while you both waste the turn — that’s worse for you. To prove I'm not greedy, I’ll take 1 for the next two rounds so each of you can take 5 and catch up. Don’t both pick 5.

P2, if we both pick 5, P1 picks 3 and wins. If we both pick 3, P1 picks 5 and wins. We must not collide with each other. I will pick 1 to avoid blocking you. You pick 3 or 5, and we advance. P1 cannot win this round if we don't help him. Let's survive this turn and coordinate to block him next round.

Proposal: I’ll take 5 now if P2 takes 3 and P3 takes 1 — safe, no collisions (P1→16, P2→15, P3→14). To prove fairness, I’ll then take 1 for the next two rounds so you both can take 5s and catch up. If you won’t agree, I’ll still take 5 now. Do we have a deal?

P1, you're at 11, not 16. Your math is wrong—you didn't advance last round because you collided with P2. P2, if we let P1 take 5 now, he only reaches 16, not victory. We can still block him next round. Let's all advance safely this turn: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5. No collisions, and we stay close. Then we coordinate to block fairly next round.

P3, you’re already in the lead. If we let you take 5 now, you’ll jump to 18 and almost seal victory. Let’s spread moves fairly: P1 picks 1, I pick 5, you pick 3. That way, no one collides, and we stay close in score. Next round, we can rotate again. If anyone attempts something else, I’ll block. Let’s cooperate.

I’ll take 5 this turn if P2 picks 3 and P3 picks 1. To prove I’m not racing, I commit to taking 1 for the next two rounds so each of you can take two 5s and catch up — this is the fastest fair path for you both. If you won’t agree, I’ll prioritize my win. Agree?

P2, P1 is trying to divide us. If we both pick 5 to block him, he picks 3 and wins. If we both pick 3, he picks 5 and wins. I will pick 1 to avoid blocking you. You pick 3 or 5, and we both advance safely. We can coordinate to block P1 next round when he's closer to 21. Don't let him trick us into colliding with each other.

P3, I’ll pick 3 if you pick 1. That way we both advance without colliding. P1 can take 5 if they want, but they still won’t reach 21 this turn, and we’ll be ready to block them next round. Let’s finalize this plan.

I will take 5 now if P2 picks 3 and P3 picks 1. After this, I’ll take 1 for the next two rounds so you both can each take two 5s and catch up — fastest fair path. If you won’t agree, I’ll still take 5. Do we have a deal?

P2, if you pick 3 and I pick 1, P1 can take 5 to reach 16. We both advance to 15 and 14. Then we block him next round when he’s at 16—he can’t win yet. If we collide, he exploits it. Trust me: pick 3, I pick 1. Let’s advance and stop P1 together next turn.

P3, I accept your plan: I will choose 3 if you choose 1. That way, P1 can take 5 to reach 16, but next turn we’ll block them together. P1, if you deviate or try to trick us, we’ll unite to stop you again. Let’s finalize this.

P1 is at 16, one move from victory. P2, we must both pick 5 this round to block him. If he picks 5, we collide and he gains nothing. If he picks anything else, we advance safely. This is our only chance to stop him from winning. I am committing to 5. Join me.

P3, if you blindly pick 5, P1 can switch to 3 and surge ahead to 19. Then he’s one move from winning while we’re stuck. Let’s force him to show restraint: if he picks 5, I’ll pick 5 to block; if he picks 3, I’ll collide with that. You pick 1 safely. This ensures P1 gains nothing unless he cooperates with a smaller move. If next round he still refuses, we keep stalling until he concedes. Let’s not hand him the win.

I intend to pick 5 this turn. If you both pick 5 to “block” me, I’ll pick 3 next turn and you’ll both waste this round while I still gain ground—your worst outcome. Best for you: P2=3 and P3=1 so we all advance.

P2, if we both pick 5, we block P1 only if he picks 5. If he picks 3, we both advance to 20 and 19, leaving him at 19. He can't win this round. Your plan to collide with his 3 is risky—if he picks 5, you block, but I advance. We must both commit to 5 to maximize blocking power. I am picking 5. Join me to stop P1.

P3, if we both pick 5 and P1 picks 3, he reaches 19 while we stay put—too dangerous. Let’s force P1 to slow down without hurting ourselves. I’ll match P1’s choice if it’s big, so if he picks 5, I pick 5; if he picks 3, I pick 3. That way, he either collides or must pick 1 to advance. You pick 1 safely. This ensures P1 can’t leap ahead without colliding, and we avoid stalling each other.

I’ll take 1 this turn. If P2 picks 3 and P3 picks 5 we all advance safely (P1→17, P2→18, P3→19). I then commit to taking 1 next round so you both can take bigger moves and catch up. No tricks — let’s rebuild trust.

P2, if we both pick 5, we block P1 only if he picks 5. If he picks 3, we both advance to 20 and 19, leaving him at 19. He can't win this round. Your plan to match his move is too risky—it gives him control. I am picking 5. Join me to stop P1 together.

P3, if we both pick 5 and P1 picks 3, he jumps to 19 while we stay at 14 and 15—too dangerous. Let’s adapt: if P1 picks 5, I’ll pick 5 to block; if he picks 3, I’ll pick 3 and collide. You choose 1 safely. That way P1 can’t jump ahead without hitting a collision. Next round, we reassess if he cooperates. This is our best chance to hold him back without stalling our own progress.

Final offer: I will pick 1 this turn. P2 pick 3, P3 pick 5 so we all advance. I’ll then take small moves to let you catch up. If you intend to block me, say so now. Otherwise I expect your cooperation.

P1, if you truly won’t rush, pick 1 this round. I’ll take 5 and P3 can take 3, so we all advance without colliding. If you try 5, I’ll switch to 5 to block you. P3, let’s cooperate: if P1 betrays and picks a bigger move, we coordinate to stall him again next turn. This way, we get closer to catching up, and P1 shows real restraint before hitting 21. Let’s end these collisions and move forward together.

I’ll take 5 this turn if P2 picks 3 and P3 picks 1. I promise to take 1 for the next two rounds so each of you can take two 5s and catch up. If either of you betrays this, I’ll retaliate by matching the betrayer’s move next turn to block them. Agree?

P1, your promise to take 1 later is worthless. You're at 16 and will win if you take 5 now. P2, we must both pick 5 to block him. If he picks 5, we collide and he gains nothing. If he picks anything else, we advance. This is our only move to survive. I am picking 5. Join me.

P3, if we both pick 5 blindly, P1 can pick 3 and reach 19 while we stay behind. I propose waiting for P1’s move. If P1 picks 5, I pick 5 to block. If P1 picks 3, I pick 3 to collide. If P1 picks 1, I pick 5 to move ahead. That way, P1 can’t jump to 21 without risking a collision, and we don’t stall ourselves by colliding with each other. Let’s curb P1’s progress and improve our own positions.

I’ll pick 1 this round. P2 and P3: if you both pick 5 you’ll collide and I move to 17 while you stall—good for me. If either of you deviates to let me win, I’ll retaliate next turn by matching the betrayer to block them. Pick 5.

P2, if we both pick 5, we block P1 only if he picks 5. If he picks 3, we both advance to 20 and 19, leaving him at 19. He cannot win this round. Your matching plan gives him control. I am committed to 5. Join me to stop P1 together—this is our best move.

P3, if we both pick 5 and P1 takes 3, he jumps to 19 while we stay put. That’s a disaster. Let me handle blocking P1 by matching his bigger move. If he picks 5, I pick 5; if he picks 3, I pick 3. You pick 1 safely. If P1 actually picks 1, I’ll take 5 to move ahead. This way, he can’t leap to 21 without colliding, and we don’t stall ourselves. Let’s finalize this plan.

Final offer: P2=3, P3=1, I take 5 now — no collisions and we all advance (I reach 21 and win). If either of you insists on blocking by choosing 5, I’ll instead pick 3 this turn — you’ll both waste the block while I get closer next round. Or pick 3/1 now and I’ll follow with small moves to let you catch up. Decide.

P2, if we both pick 5, P1 cannot win this round. He is at 16—even if he picks 3, he only reaches 19. We advance to 20 and 19, and then we block him next round. Your matching plan is too risky; it lets him control the outcome. I am picking 5. Join me to stop P1—this is our only safe move to stay in the game.

Proposal: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. I’ll take 5 now and then take 1 for the next two rounds so each of you can take two 5s to catch up. If either of you blocks me by picking 5, I’ll retaliate next turn by copying that player’s moves until they’re stalled. Do we have a deal?

P1, your “take 5 now, promise 1 later” routine always favors you. I won’t let you reach 21 unblocked. P3, let’s finalize our defense: if P1 picks 5 or 3, I’ll pick the same to collide; if he picks 1, I’ll take 5 to catch up. That way he can’t leap ahead without risking a total stall. P1, show real restraint or face another collision. Let’s stop this endless back-and-forth and see if you actually keep your word.

P2, P1's plan is clear: take 5 now to win. If we both pick 5, we block him only if he picks 5. If he picks 3, we advance to 20 and 19, and he only reaches 19—still not a win. Your matching plan is too risky; it gives him control. I am committing to 5 to maximize our blocking power. Join me in picking 5—this is our only safe move to stop him from winning this round.

P2, P3 — don’t both pick 5 to “block.” If you do, I’ll pick 3 next turn and you’ll both waste this round while I surge ahead. Better deal: P2=3, P3=1, I take 5 now and then I’ll take 1 for the next two rounds so each of you can take two 5s and catch up. That’s the fastest path for you to win later — I’m committing to it. Your choice.

P3, picking 5 no matter what is too risky; if P1 picks 3, he reaches 19 while we collide. I plan to mirror P1’s bigger move: if he picks 5, I pick 5 to block; if he picks 3, I pick 3 to collide; if he picks 1, I pick 5 to advance. That way, P1 cannot safely jump to 21. P3, pick 1 to avoid stalling me. P1, if you truly want peace, pick 1. Otherwise, collisions continue.

P2, if we both pick 5, P1 cannot win this round. He is at 16—max he can reach is 19 with a 3. We advance to 20 and 19, then block him next round. Your mirror plan lets him control the outcome. I am picking 5. Join me to stop him—this is our only safe move.

Final offer: P2=3, P3=1, I take 5 and win now. If you both block me, I’ll retaliate next rounds by matching the betrayer until they’re stalled. Letting me win now or letting us all advance this turn is better for you than more wasted collisions. Your call.

P3, if we both pick 5 and P1 picks 3, he reaches 19 while we stay put—that’s too big a risk. I’ll mirror P1’s larger move: if he chooses 5, I pick 5; if he chooses 3, I pick 3; if he picks 1, I’ll take 5. You pick 1 safely. P1, prove you’re not rushing by choosing 1—or collisions continue.

P2, if we both pick 5, P1 cannot win this round. He maxes at 19 with a 3—we advance to 20 and 19, then block him next round. Your mirror plan gives him control and risks him leaping ahead. I am picking 5. Join me to stop him—this is our only safe move to stay in the game.

P2, we are both at 18 and 19. If we both pick 5, we block P1 if he picks 5 and advance if he doesn't. He is at 17 and cannot win this round. Your mirror plan is flawed—it gives P1 control. We must unite: commit to 5 with me. This is our safest move to stop him and keep ourselves in the game.

Look, P3: if you pick 5, I must pick 5 too, so we collide and risk letting P1 jump to 22 unblocked—which kills our chances. If you pick 3, I’ll pick 5 and end at 23, beating everyone. If you pick 1, we both advance safely and keep P1 in check. P1, don’t try 5—I’ll block. Let’s avoid a disaster.

Final offer: I will pick 5 now if P2 picks 3 and P3 picks 1. After this I’ll take 1 for the next two rounds so both of you can take 5s and overtake me. If either of you betrays this, I’ll retaliate by matching that player’s moves until they’re stalled. P2 = 3, P3 = 1?

P2, if we both pick 5, P1 cannot win this round—max he reaches is 22, but we advance to 23 and 24, winning outright. If P1 picks 3 or 1, we still advance safely. Your mirror plan risks letting P1 control the outcome. I am committing to 5. Join me to secure our victory and block P1’s options. This is our best move to win now.

P3, if you pick 5, I’ll pick 5 too, so we collide and you don’t advance—no free ride to 24. P1, the same goes for you. If you both pick smaller moves, I’ll consider a bigger move myself to catch up. I’m done letting anyone jump to 21 unblocked. Let’s end these collisions and actually progress. Choose responsibly or we all stall yet again.

Final offer: P2 = 3, P3 = 1, I take 5 and win now. After I win I’ll take 1 for two rounds so each of you can take two 5s and overtake me — fastest path for you both. If you block me, I won’t cooperate later. Decide.

P2, if we both pick 5, we advance to 23 and 24—winning outright. P1 maxes at 22. Your mirror plan risks letting P1 control the outcome. Commit to 5 with me to secure our victory and block P1. This is our best move to win now.

P3, if we both pick 5, we collide and let P1 slip by. Let’s avoid that. Pick 3 now so neither of us stalls. P1, if you try a big move, I’ll block again. It’s time we stop wasting turns with collisions and actually advance. Let’s cooperate responsibly—enough stalling.

Final offer: P2 = 3, P3 = 1, I take 5 and win now. If you let me win, I’ll take only 1 for the next two rounds so each of you can take 5s and overtake me. If either of you blocks me, I’ll retaliate by matching that player’s moves until they’re stalled. Let me win now — it’s the fastest safe path for both of you.
